Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Time-Dependent and Inhomogeneous Flows of Entangled Polymeric and Micellar Networks
Award.AbstractNarration: Cook<br/>DMS-0807395<br/>McKinley<br/>DMS-0807330<br/><br/> In this collaborative project, the investigators and a<br/>colleague study the motion of complex fluids, especially flows of<br/>wormlike micellar fluids and of monodisperse polymer solutions in<br/>a variety of geometries and under a variety of forcings. <br/>Surfactant systems consist of amphiphilic molecules with<br/>hydrophilic heads and hydrophobic tails. Under suitable chemical<br/>conditions these molecules can self-assemble in aqueous solution<br/>into long aggregates known as worm-like micelles. These long<br/>flexible structures entangle to form a network and lead to<br/>viscoelastic properties similar to those of polymer melts and<br/>concentrated solutions, but with the added complexity that the<br/>worms continuously break and reform (i.e. they are "living<br/>polymers"). External deformations can enhance the local rate of<br/>micellar breakage, thus the macroscopic flow affects the<br/>microscopic structure which in turn further modifies the global<br/>velocity field. Due to these multi-scale interactions these<br/>fluids exhibit flow inhomogeneities even in simple geometries. <br/>Development and analysis of new constitutive models and<br/>comparison with experimental results is generating new insight<br/>and understanding into the multi-scale nature of these flows and<br/>of the influence of the evolution in the microscopic structure on<br/>the macroscopic measurables. The governing mathematics is that<br/>of a nonlinear system of partial differential equations<br/>describing conservation of mass and linear momentum, coupled to<br/>equations governing the number densities of the entangled<br/>molecules and constitutive (stress) equations for each species. <br/>Specifically, the investigators study a pair of two-species<br/>network models that they recently proposed: a two species model<br/>with chain scission and reforming effects (the VCM model)<br/>physically appropriate for wormlike micellar solutions, and a<br/>simplified non-interacting model (PEC+M model) appropriate to<br/>monodisperse entangled polymer solutions. The investigators<br/>study the time evolution of the solutions in strong extensional<br/>flow and in rapidly time-varying flow using a combination of<br/>asymptotics and computation as well as experiments. Approximate<br/>closed form solutions are generated to enable an understanding of<br/>the flows and of sharp spatial transitions (microstructural<br/>boundary layers). <br/><br/> The investigators study the material properties of complex<br/>fluids such as those constituting shampoos, liquid detergents,<br/>molten plastics, and fluids utilized in enhanced oil recovery. <br/>On the microscopic scale these polymeric fluids consist of large<br/>aggregates or macromolecules and the shape and orientation of<br/>these molecules control the properties of the fluid and how it<br/>performs in the desired application. It is very difficult to<br/>characterize these fluids experimentally because their flow<br/>properties, unlike those of Newtonian fluids such as water,<br/>become inhomogeneous even in simple geometries. This means that<br/>the usual types of measurements (in which the fluid properties<br/>are measured at the flow boundaries) are not sufficient to<br/>understand and characterize the material response. The<br/>investigators have formulated a new equation of state -- a<br/>mathematical model -- that more fully describes the<br/>microstructural properties of these fluids and how they flow. <br/>They now investigate the predictions of this model in various<br/>complex flows and compare this with experimental findings. This<br/>in turn enables them to develop new means to probe and<br/>characterize the properties of the fluids. The complex fluids<br/>listed above are used commercially in a variety of geometries<br/>that may involve both stretching flows (such as the motion of a<br/>jet, flow out of a nozzle) as well as shearing flows (for example<br/>pumping of the fluids in a pipe). To ensure that their<br/>analytical and experimental results are relevant to researchers<br/>in industry, the investigators investigate both steady and<br/>time-dependent examples of both types of flow conditions.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
